node.title: ‘Procession’ Review: Art as Exorcism
node.alt: From left, Ed Gavagan, Michael Sandridge and Dan Laurine in the documentary “Procession.”
node.description: In this experimental documentary streaming on Netflix, six survivors of abuse within the Catholic Church use filmmaking to confront traumatic memories.
node.content: ["Robert Greene\u2019s two most recent documentaries pondered the ethics of re-enacting traumatic events, with an interest in immersion\u2019s psychological effects on performers. \u201cKate Plays Christine\u201d followed an actress as she prepared to play a newscaster who killed herself on the air. \u201cBisbee \u201917\u201d watched the residents of an Arizona town as they recreated a large-scale deportation that had occurred there a century earlier.", "With \u201cProcession,\u201d Greene pushes the concept of staging-as-exorcism to an extreme: Can men who endured childhood sexual abuse within the Catholic Church confront painful memories through filmmaking \u2014 and perhaps gain some solace from that process? The movie is billed as a three-year collaboration among six abuse survivors, a professional drama therapist and the director and his crew. In an expansive \u201cfilm by\u201d credit, Greene gives the victims top billing.", "\u201cProcession\u201d follows the men as they help one another brainstorm and shoot five scripted scenes based on their experiences. Various elements of the production process (casting, costuming, finding locations the subjects haven\u2019t visited since youth) become means for coping and reckoning. A sixth survivor, Tom Viviano, says he cannot tell his story because it\u2019s still before the courts. His contribution is to act \u2014 playing predator priests, in what must be agonizing feats of impersonation \u2014 in two segments.", "\u201cProcession\u201d is exceptionally difficult to watch, as it should be. It\u2019s also difficult to assess as art, given how it collapses lines between collaboration and co-option and between cinema and supportive treatment. To judge Greene\u2019s experiment, not least because of its visible salutary effects, feels like intruding on private breakthroughs. But the discomfiting power of \u201cProcession\u201d comes from its ability to show and, to all appearances, facilitate them."]
